column13: What is the weirdest question you've ever gotten from a reader?
column14: What are you most looking forward to about the Collingswood Book Festival? (if you've been here before)

column3:
Malik Abduh is a poet and essayist. He earned an MFA in Creative Writing from Rutgers University-Camden, where he received the 2008 Rutgers University Alumni Association Creative Writing Award. He teaches English at Rowan College at Burlington County and is the editor of the College’s journal, <i>The Baron Anthology<i>. His work appears in several journals and magazines, including <i>Southern Indiana Review<i>, <i>Four Way Review<i>, <i>Exit 7, <i>Slush<i>, and <i>Some Call it Ballin’ Magazine<i>. His debut collection, <i>All the Stars Aflame,<i> is published by Get Fresh Books Publishing.

In his debut collection, <i>All the Stars Aflame,<i>'' he relates the brutal legacy of U.S. racial violence, including lynchings, riots, uprisings, and political assassinations, told in the voices of those who experienced these tragedies firsthand. Likewise, Abduh chronicles his own life experiences: sneaking as a young boy to listen to Richard Pryor records, lamenting the gentrification of his old neighborhood, and struggling to build his daughter a doll house. Thus, this volume is a balance between historical record and personal narrative. Rich with vivid imagery, tragic irony, anddark humor, <i>All the Stars Aflame<i> is a timely poetic debut.

Henry Brann is a writer and poet who has self-published two chapbooks of haiku, The Moon and the Cross and Windswept. He founded the Upright Remington Press and published its first edition, Writers House Poetry, Volume 1, haiku, senryu, and tanka. Mr. Brann, as a board member of the Nick Virgilio Haiku Association and Writers House, has for many years administered with poet Robin Palley the Nick Virgilio Memorial Haiku/Senryu Competition, which is hosted by the Haiku Society of America. Henry has read his work at City Lights Books, the NewYorican Poets Cafe, Fergies, national and regional conferences - Haiku North America, the Dodge Poetry Festival, Haiku Society of America and the Collingswood Book Festival and most recently at the Somers Point Poetry Festival. Henry directed and later produced as a film the play Nick of Time, Nick of Time written by Joseph M. Paprzycki, which focused on the last hours of the poet’s life. The play was first shown at the Waterfront South Theater in Camden, Nick’s hometown. The film was initially screened at HNA, Santa Fe. Mr. Brann has participated in the Collingswood Book Festival for more than a dozen years as a representative of the Nick Virgilio Haiku Association, the Wall of Haiku, also as a reader, writer, and teacher of haiku and related forms.
column4:
Nick Virgilio, A Life in Haiku
Nick Virgilio Writers House Poetry, Volume 1
Writers House Poetry Volume 2
column13: When I was asked if the title of my chapbook “Windswept” meant wind swept or winds wept. It made me curious as well.
column14: Seeing old friends, reading my work, promoting the Wall of Haiku

column3: Anthony Cappo is the author of the poetry chapbook, When You're Deep in a Thing (Four Way Books, 2022) and My Bedside Radio. His poems and other writings have appeared in Thrush Poetry Journal, Prelude, The Rumpus, Yes Poetry, and other publications. Anthony received his MFA in creative writing from Sarah Lawrence College. He grew up in Cherry Hill, New Jersey and now lives in New York City.
column4: "When You're Deep in a Thing" Publication date September 15, 2022. ISBN 978-1-954245-33-4
column14: I'm greatly looking forward to being in South Jersey and reading poems in the place where many of them germinated.

column3: Joel Dias-Porter (aka DJ Reneg8d) originally from Pittsburgh, PA and currently resides in South Jersey. The 1998 & 1999 Haiku Slam Champion, his poems have been published in POETRY, Mead, Best American Poetry 2014, Callaloo, Antioch Review, Red Brick Review, and the anthologies, Short Fuse, Role Call, Def Poetry Jam, 360 Degrees of Black Poetry, Slam (The Book), Poetry Nation, Beyond the Frontier, and Catch a Fire. A Cave Canem Fellow, he also received the Furious Flower "Emerging Poet Award" in 1995. His collection Ideas of Improvisation is on Thread Makes Blanket Press.

Emari DiGiorgio is the author of Girl Torpedo, winner of the Numinous Orison, Luminous Origin Literary Award, and The Things a Body Might Become. Her poetry has received numerous awards, including the Auburn Witness Poetry Prize, RHINO’s Founder’s Prize and a poetry fellowship from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. At Stockton University, Emari teaches first-year writing and poetry, is the Faculty Director of Murphy Writing, and serves as President of the Stockton Federation of Teachers. She is also a Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation Poet and hosts World Above, a monthly reading series in Atlantic City, NJ.
column4:
The Things a Body Might Become – August 25, 2017 – ISBN-10 ‏ : ‎ 1944355383; ISBN-13 ‏ : ‎ 978-1944355388

Girl Torpedo – February 1, 2018 – ISBN-10 ‏ : ‎ 1939675626; ISBN-13 ‏ : ‎ 978-1939675620

column3: Anna M. Evans’ poems have appeared in the Harvard Review, Atlanta Review, Rattle, American Arts Quarterly, and 32 Poems. She gained her MFA from Bennington College. Recipient of Fellowships from the MacDowell Artists' Colony and the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts, and winner of the 2012 Rattle Poetry Prize Readers' Choice Award, she currently teaches at West Windsor Art Center and Rowan College at Burlington County. Her books include her latest chapbooks, The Quarantina Chronicles (Barefoot Muse Press, 2020) and The Unacknowledged Legislator (Empty Chair Press, 2019), along with Under Dark Waters: Surviving the Titanic (Able Muse Press, 2018), and her sonnet collection, Sisters & Courtesans (White Violet Press, 2014).
column4:
Under Dark Waters: Surviving the Titanic, Able Muse Press, 2018, ISBN 978-1-77349-012-0

Sisters & Courtesans, White Violet Press, 2014, ISBN 9780615983141

column3: Leah Falk is the author of two collections of poetry, To Look After and Use (Finishing Line Press, 2019) and Other Customs and Practices (Glass Lyre Press, 2023). Her work has appeared in The Kenyon Review, Best New Poets, Electric Literature, FIELD, and elsewhere. She's received support for her writing from the Vermont Studio Center, Asylum Arts, the Yiddish Book Center, and the Sundress Academy for the Arts. Since 2016, she has directed campus and community programming at the Rutgers-Camden Writers House. She lives in Philadelphia with her family.
column4: To Look After and Use, September 2019, 978-1-64662-035-7

column3: Faleeha Hassan is a poet, teacher, editor, writer, and playwright born in Najaf, Iraq, in 1967, who now lives in the United States. Faleeha is the first woman to write poetry for children in Iraq. She received her master's degree in Arabic literature, and has now published 25 books. Ms. Hassan has received many awards in Iraq and throughout the Middle East for her poetry and short stories. Faleeha Hassan has also had her poems and short stories published in a variety of American magazines such as: Philadelphia Poets 22, Harbinger Asylum, Brooklyn Rail Screaming Mamas, The Galway Review, Words Without Borders, SJ Magazine, Scarlet Leaf Review, Taos Journal, Indiana Voice Journal, The Blue Mountain Review, Taos Journal of Poetry and Art, American Poetry Review, Oprah Magazine, and many others. Her most recent books include Breakfast with Butterflies, A Butterfly’s Voice, and War and Me. She has received a number of awards and honors, including the inspiration award as part of SJ Magazine’s 2020 Women of Excellent. She has also been nominated for the Pulitzer Prize and Pushcart Prize.
column4: (War and Me ) a memoir book ,publishing in Amazon, it's will be available on Amazon on August 1st 2022, ISBN 978-1542036184

column3: Laura McCullough is the author of eight collections of poetry including Panic, winner of the Kinereth Gensler Award with Alice James Books, Wild Night Dress, selected by Billy Collins in the Miller Williams Series with Arkansas University Press, and her most recent book, Women & Other Hostages with Black Lawrence Press. A three time New Jersey State Arts Council Fellow, she has won numerous fellowships and prizes and appeared in Best American Poetry. She has edited two essays collections on poetry, The Room and the World: Essays on the Poet Stephen Dunn and A Sense of Regard: Essays on Poetry and Race. She teaches at Brookdale Community College and is on the faculty of the Reno Nevada MFA program.
column4:
The Room and the World: Essays on the Poet Stephen Dunn. ISBN. ‎978-0815633358

Women and Other Hostages. ISBN. 978-1625578396
column12: As a teacher, I love talking craft with people and hearing about their projects.
column13:
Ha! I was giving a reading in Florida the year I was the Florida Writers circuit poet. During a Q and A, someone asked if I believed in God or gods and what I felt was sacred in the world. It wasn’t a weird question so much as a highly profound but possibly provocative one, but it led to a discussion of art and poetry and their relationship to both the sacred and the profane. 

The toughest question I was ever asked was by a young man after a discussion of a Tony Hoagland poem. He said he didn’t mean to be offensive, but he wanted to know what Hoagland meant by the difference between having sex and making love. He was the only identified male in a workshop of all women. It was a brave question and the discussion that followed left some of us in tears but all of us a little kinder.
column14:
Doing the event with BJ Ward on Stephen Dunn 

I have a new book out myself.

column3: Bruce W. Niedt is a retired “beneficent bureaucrat” whose poetry has been published in dozens of online and print journals, including Rattle, Writer’s Digest, Mason Street Review, Boston Literary Magazine, Tiferet, Spitball, and Your Daily Poem. His work has also appeared in the anthologies Best of the Barefoot Muse, Poem Your Heart Out, and most recently, Poetry for Ukraine. He has won poetry awards from Writer’s Digest, ByLine Magazine, and the Philadelphia Writers Conference, as well as three Pushcart Prize nominations and two Best of the Net nominations. He has had the good fortune to participate in poetry workshops led by Billy Collins, Jane Hirshfield, and Marge Piercy, to name a few. He has had two books of poetry released in 2022: his first full-length collection, The Bungalow of Colorful Aging, from Kelsay Books, and his eighth chapbook, Knit Our Broken Bones, from Maverick Duck Press. A proud father of four and grandfather of three, he lives with his incredibly patient wife in Cherry Hill, NJ.
column4: The Bungalow of Colorful Aging, Kelsay Books 02/02/2022, ISBN 9781639800643
column12: Just the validation of knowing that they may have heard or read my work and been moved or inspired by it in some way. I always appreciate the opportunity to share my work publicly.
column13: I can't think of any particularly weird questions, but one my most unusual experiences was discovering during an online search that someone had translated a political poem of mine into Bengali and read it as a performance piece. They did credit me as the author though. I was surprised and flattered.
column14: The variety of local and regional authors and poets eager to share their creative products in a block-party type of atmosphere, in one of South Jersey's best business districts. Of course, I always enjoy what's happening in the Poetry Tent.

column3: Robin Palley is a haiku poet and president of Camden's Nick Virgilio Haiku Association and the Writers House. Robin has represented NVHA at Haiku North America and with her partner, poet Henry Brann, runs the Virgilio Haiku and Senryu Contest of the Haiku Society of America. Robin was a top 10 winner in the Seabeck Haiku Getaway 2020 Annual Kukai:. Her work has been published in anthologies of the Haiku Society of America and the Nick Virgilio Haiku Association and will appear in an upcoming issue of HSA's Frogpond.
column4:
Nick Virgilio Writers House Poetry: Volume 1: haiku, senryu, and tanka. July 30, 2019 ISBN 9780578550701

Nick Virgilio Writers House Poetry 2020: Volume 2: Haiku In Action Paperback – October 21, 2021
